---1263818609-809177363-1321320352=:47886
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Hi,

=C2=A0If the gradient-based optimizer modify the phenotype, at each ge=
notype evaluation, yes, I would see this as an iterated transformation. Goo=
d example of this would be optimization of a perceptron, for a supervised l=
earning problem. The genotype would be the structure of perceptron, and som=
e parameters for an initialization heuristic. The initial phenotype would b=
e a perceptron decoded from the genotype. Then, the development would be a =
retro-propagation training of that perceptron. Retro-propagation is a gradi=
ent-based optimization, using local informations. I'm sure such a thing cro=
ssed many minds ^^

If the gradient-based optimizer modify the genotype, no=
. So if the genotype is directly the weights of a fixed-topology perceptron=
, nope.

I can post my HyperNEAT setup quite soon, and I should have done t=
his since a while, lazy me... I had to do some a bit of engineering in the =
code, to make it compilable on the cluster I was using. So although it's th=
e genuine original HyperNEAT code, some cosmetic chirurgy happened. More im=
portant, you got the fitness function for the problem. =C2=A0I just need to=
 write a little bit of documentation on how to compile and use the whole me=
ss. I'll post it on my website and send an=C2=A0announcement=C2=A0of this. =
Can be done within few days.

Cheers,
Alex

_______________________________=
_
De=C2=A0: afcarl2 <afcarl2@...>
=C3=80=C2=A0: neat@yahoogroups.com
=
Envoy=C3=A9 le : Mardi 15 Novembre 2011 8h51
Objet=C2=A0: Re: Re : Re : Re =
: [neat] Any Prior Applications of NEAT In Which The Genotype Itself Is The=
 Output?


=C2=A0 


Alex,
If an individual maps to a point evaluation of t=
he design space, and the local jacobian of the fitness landscape is such th=
at an added local gradient based sub-optimization task follows a trajectory=
 resulting in an improved fitness associated w/ an updated individual, woul=
d that satisfy the classification requirements associated w/ "implicit evol=
ved embryogeny"? Also, would you consider uploading your updated version of=
 Hyperneat used in your study to the group file repository?
Thanks,
Andy

-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi=
,
> =C3=82=C2=A0 I'm not 100% sure to get the whole meaning of your questio=
n, so I might answer a bit off-target ^^
> 
> =C3=82=C2=A0 In that paragrap=
h about the taxonomy (end of page 4), I mention "local information". It's n=
ot a gradient, as in "gradient based optimization", that is, a clue on the =
local geometry of the objective function. By "local information", I mean, *=
any* kind of local feedback of the behavior of the phenotype. If we optimiz=
e a plane wing, it could be, say, the local air pressure. If we optimize a =
heat exchanger, it would be local heath flux. If we optimize a water pipe n=
etwork, it would the local water flux and pressure.
> 
> 
> =C3=82=C2=A0The=
n, does this local information feeback turns "external non-evolved embryoge=
ny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny" ? It's quite a fuzzy territory, if y=
ou ask me. Let's say you decode the genotype as a transformation of an init=
ial phenotype to a final one. You have many many ways to do this, and you c=
an have genotype as a very flexible transformation (many many development s=
teps, each doing small changes in all possible ways) or a very inflexible o=
ne (1 single very had-hoc transformation step). So between "external non-ev=
olved embryogeny" and "implicit evolved embryogeny", I believe there is a w=
hole gradient of possibilities rather than a sharp border between the two. =
Actually, to have a trully "implicit evolved embryogeny", it would unbounde=
d development. But in practice, allowing a few steps of development brings =
a lot of flexibility for a genotype, so it's a rethoritical remark.
> 
> Ch=
eers,
> 
> Alex
> 
> 
> ________________________________

> Alex,
> Thank you for the =
link! Question: In your opinion, does the added presence of local gradient-=
based optimization of the design space transition the classification defini=
tion from "external non-evolved embryogeny" to "implicit evolved embryogeny=
"? BTW, I am attracted to your more flexible taxonomy, as I have never been=
 fully comfortable with the spatial transformation constraint assumption.
>=
 Thanks,
> Andy
>

      <div><br>
<br>
Alex,<=
br>
If an individual maps to a point evaluation of the design space, and th=
e local jacobian of the fitness landscape is such that an added local gradi=
ent based sub-optimization task follows a trajectory resulting in an improv=
ed fitness associated w/ an updated individual, would that satisfy the clas=
sification requirements associated w/ "implicit evolved embryogeny"? Also, =
would you consider uploading your updated version of Hyperneat used in your=
 study to the group file repository?<br>
Thanks,<br>
Andy<br>
<br>
--- In <=
a rel=3D"nofollow" ymailto=3D"mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_bla=
nk" href=3D"mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, Alexan=
dre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:<br>
><br>
> Hi,<br>
> =C3=
=82  I'm not 100% sure to get the whole meaning of your question, so I=
 might answer a bit off-target ^^<br>
> <br>
> =C3=82  In that p=
aragraph about the taxonomy (end of page 4), I mention "local information".=
 It's not a gradient, as in "gradient based optimization", that is, a clue =
on the local geometry of the objective function. By "local information", I =
mean, *any* kind of local feedback of the behavior of the phenotype. If we =
optimize a plane wing, it could be, say, the local air pressure. If we opti=
mize a heat exchanger, it would be local heath flux. If we optimize a water=
 pipe network, it would the local water flux and pressure.<br>
> <br>
&g=
t; <br>
> =C3=82 Then, does this local information feeback turns "e=
xternal non-evolved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny" ? It's q=
uite a fuzzy territory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode the genotype as=
 a transformation of an initial phenotype to a final one. You have many man=
y ways to do this, and you can have genotype as a very flexible transformat=
ion (many many development steps, each doing small changes in all possible =
ways) or a very inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transformation step).=
 So between "external non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit evolved embryog=
eny", I believe there is a whole gradient of possibilities rather than a sh=
arp border between the two. Actually, to have a trully "implicit evolved em=
bryogeny", it would unbounded development. But in practice, allowing a few =
steps of development brings a lot of flexibility for a genotype, so it's a =
rethoritical remark.<br>
> <br>
> Cheers,<br>
> <br>
> Alex<br>=
